title: How to Make Vegan Bouillabaisse

steps.headline: Heat the olive oil in a soup pot over medium heat until the oil is shimmering.
Add the leek and the garlic cloves and cook them for 3 minutes or until they are slightly softened.
steps.description: Stir them often with a wooden spoon.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the garlic and leeks with salt and pepper.
Add the fennel, celery, carrots, and spices into the pot and cook them for about 5 minutes, making sure to stir them often so that the vegetables don’t caramelize.
Add the tomato paste and cook for 1 more minute.
Whisk together the wine and the saffron threads in a small bowl.
Add the wine and saffron mixture, the orange peel and 3-1/2 cups of vegetable broth to the pot.
Simmer the soup base for 25 minutes, until the vegetables are soft when you pierce them with a fork.
Remove the soup pot from the heat and cool the soup for 5 minutes.

methods.name: Puree the Soup in a Blender or Food Processor

steps.headline: Ladle the soup into a blender pitcher or food processor.
Run the blender or food processor at its lowest setting, stopping when the soup is roughly pureed.
steps.description: You want the texture to be thickened but chunky.

steps.headline: Return the roughly pureed soup to the pot.
Add the reserved slice half of the fennel bulb to the top right corner of the soup (between 12:00 and 2:00).
Add the artichoke hearts between 2:00 and 4:00.
steps.description: Continue adding the potatoes, white beans and baby carrots, circling around the soup pot so that each vegetable has its own section.

steps.headline: Simmer the vegetables for 10 to 15 minutes.
steps.description: Occasionally, stir the soup near the bottom of the pan. You want to avoid mixing the top layer of featured vegetables, but you also want to keep the pureed vegetables from burning on the bottom of the pan.

steps.headline: Ladle the soup into bowls, getting a little of each vegetable.
Serve the soup with a slice of crusty bread that has been rubbed with olive oil and garlic.

text: Preparing the Soup Base Heat the olive oil in a soup pot over medium heat until the oil is shimmering.  Add the leek and the garlic cloves and cook them for 3 minutes or until they are slightly softened. Stir them often with a wooden spoon. Sprinkle the garlic and leeks with salt and pepper.  Add the fennel, celery, carrots, and spices into the pot and cook them for about 5 minutes, making sure to stir them often so that the vegetables don’t caramelize.  Add the tomato paste and cook for 1 more minute.  Whisk together the wine and the saffron threads in a small bowl.  Add the wine and saffron mixture, the orange peel and 3-1/2 cups of vegetable broth to the pot.  Simmer the soup base for 25 minutes, until the vegetables are soft when you pierce them with a fork.  Remove the soup pot from the heat and cool the soup for 5 minutes.  Puree the Soup in a Blender or Food Processor Ladle the soup into a blender pitcher or food processor.  Run the blender or food processor at its lowest setting, stopping when the soup is roughly pureed. You want the texture to be thickened but chunky. Return the roughly pureed soup to the pot.  Finishing the Soup Add the remaining broth.  Add the reserved slice half of the fennel bulb to the top right corner of the soup (between 12:00 and 2:00).  Add the artichoke hearts between 2:00 and 4:00. Continue adding the potatoes, white beans and baby carrots, circling around the soup pot so that each vegetable has its own section. Simmer the vegetables for 10 to 15 minutes. Occasionally, stir the soup near the bottom of the pan. You want to avoid mixing the top layer of featured vegetables, but you also want to keep the pureed vegetables from burning on the bottom of the pan. Ladle the soup into bowls, getting a little of each vegetable.  Serve the soup with a slice of crusty bread that has been rubbed with olive oil and garlic.
